name: Platform
desc: What kinds of devices will your users be using?

choices.name: Web
choices.desc: Your users will access your app from a laptop, phone, or tablet using a web browser like Chrome or Safari. This is usually cheapest, and guarantees anyone with a smartphone or computer can use your app.

choices.name: Mobile Android
choices.desc: Your users can download your app from Google Play, the Android App Store, to their Android phones or tablets.

choices.name: Mobile iOS
choices.desc: Your users can download your app from the Apple App Store to their iPhones or iPads.

name: Authentication
desc: How will your users sign in? (If you or your users aren't saving information anywhere, you might not need this at all!)

choices.name: Sign in through a social network
choices.desc: Google, Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, Github... These all provide ways of letting people log in and sign up. How many social networks do you want to include?

choices.name: Sign in without going through anyone else's site
choices.desc: This is more expensive than letting people use their social media accounts, but means you have more control over your user experience.

choices.name: Admin portal
choices.desc: Use a secure admin account to manage your users and your data.

name: Database
desc: Where does your app get all its data? Where does it save data?

choices.name: Reading from an API
choices.desc: Your app tells you whether it's raining using data from the National Weather Service, or shows graphs of basketball scores from ESPN, or visualizes data that it gets from somewhere else.

choices.name: Reading from a spreadsheet or table
choices.desc: Your app pulls data from a CSV or JSON file. This is great when your data is rarely going to change, like if you want to show data from a census or survey.

choices.name: Reading from and writing to a database
choices.desc: You want to collect and display data, and want to have total control over all of it. You may be building a complicated web of data, like a social network. A PHP back-end will be set up to handle this.

choices.name: Reading from and writing to Firebase
choices.desc: You'll have less than a hundred people using your app at any given time. It's important that your users see data change in real-time: if a person on Computer B types something in, a person on Computer A sees it immediately.

name: Data models
desc: How many different collections of data will your app have?

choices.desc: A 'model' is like one row in a spreadsheet. It's a collection of pieces of text and numbers. For example: a blog post, an event, an invitation to an event, a product, a product review, an product order... You usually add data by typing things into a form.

name: Design
desc: How much work, if any, needs to be put into your user interface?

choices.name: Heavy
choices.desc: You need to stand out visually. You may have some sketches and wireframes, but will need to graphics drawn and a layout constructed for you.

choices.name: Medium
choices.desc: Your app needs some visual customization, but you have a well-defined styleguide and you will provide all necessary images and graphics.

choices.name: Light
choices.desc: A customized user interface isn't important to your app. Bootstrap or another CSS framework will cover the bare necessities, but otherwise design can be left alone.

name: Features
desc: What else will you add to your app to make it unique?

choices.name: Capture photos
choices.desc: Collect images from your users' cameras.

choices.name: File upload
choices.desc: Let your users upload videos and documents. This is pricey because files are big, and finding a secure way to store all that data is tricky.

choices.name: Data reporting
choices.desc: Display data in a slick graphical or print-friendly fashion.

choices.name: Automatic e-mails
choices.desc: The app will use a template to automatically send e-mails.

choices.name: Analytics
choices.desc: Incorporate Google analytics or similar into your app.

choices.name: Payment processing
choices.desc: Use Stripe, PayPal, Bitcoin, or a similar third-party service to collect payments.
